Java - Jackson

Created:2018-09-17  Last modified:2018-09-17

  • Introduction
  • Example
  • References

  1. Introduction

    String <---- (ObjectMapper: transmission of bytes / string) --> Java Bean Object

    Jackson is similar to org.json, but it can convert json to Java Bean object.

    Jackson jars

    Jackson has 3 core .jar, core, databinding, and annotation.
    The core class is ObjectMapper. User-defined Java Bean.

    Jackson String Input/Output

    Jackson string can be a string, or a io object.

    The input string must be double-quote, and field name also need to be quoted.

    Jackson's restriction

    Jackson has restriction on receiving the string, which is you can define a Java Bean class to receive the JSON. However, you may not sure about which field will be returned.

    In this case, you can define Map<String, Object> to receive it. ObjectMapper will map the value into it.

  2. Example

    String to Java Bean

                    public static void main(String [] args){
                    String x = "{\"name\": \" Nan Qin \", \"success\": true, \"values\": {\"age\":21}}";
                    ObjectMapper mapper = new ObjectMapper();
                    try{
                        ResponseBean rb = mapper.readValue(x, ResponseBean.class);
                        System.out.println(rb.getValues().get("age")); // this map created by Jackson is hashmap.
                    }catch (IOException e){
                        System.out.println(e.getMessage());
                    }
                }
                package json.jackson;

import java.util.*;
public class ResponseBean {
    private boolean success;
    private String name;
    //private String [] reasons;
    private Map<String, Object> values;

    @Override
    public String toString(){
        return "name: " + name + "; success: " + success;
    }
    public boolean isSuccess(){
        return this.success;
    }

    public void setName(String name){
        this.name = name;
    }
    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }
    public Map<String, Object> getValues() {
        return values;
    }

    public void setSuccess(boolean success) {
        this.success = success;
    }
    public void setValues(Map<String, Object> values) {
        this.values = values;
    }
}

    From Java Bean to String

                    package json.jackson;
                import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectMapper;
                public class JavaBean2String {
                    public static void main(String [] args){
                        ResponseBean rb = new ResponseBean();
                        rb.setName("Nan Qin");
                        ObjectMapper mapper = new ObjectMapper();
                
                        try {
                            String json = mapper.writeValueAsString(rb);
                            System.out.println(json);
                        } catch (Exception e) {
                            e.printStackTrace();
                        }
                    }
                }
